awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel, Non-Manual Solution for Mitigating Endoscope Looping in Riskier Colonoscopies
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the development of a functional prototype for a novel abdominal compression device that prevents endoscope looping during colonoscopy, a common complication that causes pain, procedure failure, and increased risk of bowel perforation. Looping is typically countered with manual application of external pressure to the abdomen by nurses, which is inconsistently effective and can lead to staff injury.  This project proposes a novel compression device that provides a safe and effective alternative to manual abdominal pressure to improve colonoscopy outcomes. 
 
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will address the technical challenges associated with engineering a colonoscopy compression device addressing the deficiencies of existing devices in patients with low body mass index (BMI) and low abdominal tissue volume. This project will accomplish this by first characterizing the differences in pressure applied by existing colonoscopy compression devices in high versus low BMI patients using pressure mapping. The results of this study will be utilized to design an adjustable and re-usable insert system that can be used during colonoscopy to apply different amounts of focused pressure. A prototype device will be produced and tested for localized pressure within a pressure range optimize to prevent looping in a low-BMI patient.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to develop a functional prototype of an external colonoscopy compression device for low BMI patients. Relative to their performance in high BMI patients, existing colonoscopy compression devices have achieved only variable effectiveness in low BMI patient populations. Low BMI patients are prone to technically challenging colonoscopies associated with increased looping of the bowel, pain, and lower rates of procedure completion.

The project's initial objective was to characterize abdominal pressure exerted by existing colonoscopy compression device in high BMI vs. low BMI human volunteers using pressure mapping. Statistically significant differences were observed between the high and low BMI groups, with low BMI participants receiving less pressure. Next, prototype colonoscopy compression devices aimed at increasing abdominal pressure exerted in low BMI patients were developed and tested on benchtop models. These prototypes were refined based on testing results, yielding two concepts that were advanced to the third phase of the project. During the third phase, two functional prototype devices were tested on human volunteers, with pressure again characterized by pressure mapping technology.

Overall results from the project demonstrated the feasibility of colonoscopy compression devices for low BMI patients capable of delivering pressure magnitudes like those achieved in high BMI patients with existing devices. Two distinct concepts emerged from the project, each of which may have unique advantages in different clinical circumstances, and which furthermore may have benefit when used iteratively in a stepwise manner.

The overall advantage of external compression devices to support colonoscopy include established safety and effectiveness, ease of use, and interoperability with existing endoscopy technology and workflows. Optimizing these devices for low BMI patients ? the feasibility of which was established through these Phase 1 efforts - will provide considerable benefit to patients and providers alike and will be the focus of the Company's phase 2 proposal.
